"Matthew E. Hoyle=
" <matthewhoyle@...> wrote:Edy let me clarify my earlier comment. Na=
te is correct, I was pretty darn
surprised! In fact I (and probably quite a=
 few others) thought you were
joking!

Actually you and I are not so differ=
ent. I started studying Chinese and
Japanese Porcelain at age 12, and I was=
 working (part time, since I was
still at school) in the Asian Arts dept of=
 a well known Auctioneer by age
16. That said you are the only kid I ever e=
ncountered who started studying
something like this seriously like I did at=
 your age.

Perhaps you should also have a look at Antique Japanese Swords,=
 but be
careful you don't get hooked :-)

If you are interested have a look=
 here:
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm

eck out http://www.nihonto.ca

 subject as well. If you like I
will post them.

Matt

n(books,pages on which I printed much Sengoku stuff from Samurai
